Definition / general

* Neuroendocrine tumor with high proportion of pancreatic polypeptide (PP) cells* Not a WHO diagnosis

Essential features

* Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that sometimes causes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome (due to PP secretion)* May metastasize to liver

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [C25.4](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C15-C26/C25-/C25.4) - malignant neoplasm of endocrine pancreas

Sites

* May arise anywhere within pancreas

Pathophysiology

* Pancreatic polypeptide regulates endocrine and exocrine secretion by the pancreas* Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) and PP are derived from a common precursor and thus
    pancreatic polypeptide secreting tumors can also cause watery diarrhea, hypokalemia,
    achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome* It has been proposed that most / all nonfunctioning pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors represent
      pancreatic polypeptide secreting tumors ([Best Pract Res Clin Gastroenterol 2012;26:737](23582916))

Clinical features

* Can cause nonspecific abdominal pain or watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria (WDHA)
  syndrome* Patients may have [multiple endocrine neoplasia 1 syndrome (MEN1)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasMEN1.html
    ) ([Arch Surg 1984;119:508](6143548))

Diagnostic criteria

* Pancreas mass and elevated levels of fasting pancreatic polypeptide hormone

Case reports

* 46 year old woman with WDHA syndrome ([Case Rep Gastroenterol 2008;2:238](21490894))* 46 year old woman with MEN1 ([Int J Gastrointest Cancer 2002;32:153](12794252))

Treatment

* Surgery is generally curative ([World J Surg 2008;32:1815](18521664))

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Resembles all other well differentiated neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas

Sample pathology report

* Pancreas, tail, resection:
  + Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, WHO grade 2 (see synoptic report and comment)+ Comment: The patient’s clinical history of watery diarrhea, hypokalemia and achlorhydria is noted. This may be due to pancreatic polypeptide secretion by this tumor. Immunohistochemical stains for synaptophysin and chromogranin are positive and the Ki67 index is approximately 3.2%.

Differential diagnosis

* [Nonfunctional well differentiated neuroendocrine tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasWDNET.html):
  + Same microscopic appearance+ Some **PP** secretion may be seen by immunohistochemistry+ Distinction is based on serum **PP** levels* [VIPoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasvipoma.html):
    + Same microscopic appearance+ Can also cause watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome+ Distinction is based on serum **PP** levels* **Pancreatic polypeptide cell hyperplasia:**
      + Neuroendocrine hyperplasia admixed with elements of normal pancreas ([J Clin Pathol 2006;59:1087](17021132))
